mayaya.title: Mayaya ‚Äî From a personal idea to an essential tool
mayaya.description: AI bot capable of learning to play autonomously, providing statistics, a competition mode, and an in-game overlay
mayaya.subtitle: How a simple basic bot became the BombParty community‚Äôs favorite companion
mayaya.game_desc: BombParty is an online game where speed and vocabulary go hand in hand. Each round, a syllable appears (e.g., "tra"); players have a few seconds to type a word containing it ("travel", "contract", etc.) before the virtual bomb explodes. Easy to pick up, the real challenge lies in the pressure of the clock!

origin.title: Origin of Mayaya
origin.description: It all started with a simple observation: on BombParty, you couldn‚Äôt play solo or practice. No single-player mode, just public matches with random opponents. Frustrated by these limits (and admittedly a bit bored), I launched a little bot for fun

steps.title: A prank
steps.desc: Originally it was just a joke: a bot that replied ‚Äúfeur‚Äù whenever someone typed ‚Äúquoi‚Äù in chat

steps.title: The .exe tool
steps.desc: The bot gained traction, so I added fun features. When a friend wanted to try it, I packaged everything into a Python app with a simple GUI

steps.title: Then the 24/7 bot
steps.desc: Running the bot locally was nice‚Ä¶ but inconvenient. So I migrated to a Node.js bot hosted online around the clock, with over 30 commands and advanced training modes

steps.title: Finally, the overlay
steps.desc: The last hurdle was switching to chat to see scores and stats. So I added a visual overlay: a clean, responsive, modular interface

origin.conclusion: This journey‚Äîfrom simple prank to full overlay‚Äîinspired the BombParty devs to adopt many of these ideas natively!

Persistence of user preferences (GM_setValue)

Enhanced player profile

funFact.title: Fun Fact: The war of attrition against Maca
funFact.intro: When I launched Mayaya, Maca‚Äîthe BombParty staff‚Äôs enforcer‚Äîbecame a real blockade:

items.text: Only one bot was tolerated; all others were wiped out
Every ‚Äúfun‚Äù feature (profile GIFs, birthday alerts‚Ä¶) was removed in a hotfix
A stealth reCAPTCHA and WebSocket encryption to stifle any initiative

funFact.war_intro: Rather than giving up, we launched a real war of attrition:

warSteps.text: Bypassing the reCAPTCHA by simulating HTTP requests and user interactions
Intensive reverse-engineering of WebSocket traffic at every patch
Auto-adaptive scripts capable of keeping pace with real-time updates

funFact.conclusion: After a year-long tug-of-war against Maca (already widely despised by the community), he finally gave up. Before disappearing, he lifted all anti-bot protections (reCAPTCHA, obfuscation). A wave of innovative bots and new overlays swept in, and BombParty has never been more alive.

mayaya.remark_label: After two years of 24/7 operation, I stopped continuously hosting the bot due to lack of motivation to maintain the service. Other newer bots have emerged and taken up the torch, but the code remains available for local use.

arie.description: Discord bot offering a wide range of features: engaging mini-games, music streaming, customizable alerts, data storage, and much more
arie.subtitle: One single bot to replace an entire army of bots on our Discord server
arie.discord_desc: Discord is a free chat platform (voice, video, and text) extremely popular with gaming communities, students, and project teams. Each space is called a server, composed of text and voice channels. Discord bots are automated accounts capable of responding to commands and enriching the user experience (games, moderation, music, etc.).

origin.title: Origin of Arie
origin.description: Within our Discord server, the proliferation of specialized bots (music, mini-games, GPT, giveaways, etc.) became unmanageable: tedious maintenance, scattered permissions, and frequent outages (e.g., music bots relying on YouTube getting blocked). So we created Arie, guided by three principles:

steps.title: Centralization
steps.desc: Gather all truly useful features into a single bot.

steps.title: Customization
steps.desc: Offer a tailor-made experience (GPT personalities, inside-joke commands, etc.).

steps.title: Reliability
steps.desc: Ensure 24/7 availability and a polished UX (slash commands + buttons).

snapscore.title: SnapScore+ ‚Äî Local multi-account orchestration
snapscore.description: Local multi-account orchestrator based on Node.js and Puppeteer. It drives multiple Chrome profiles to send and open snaps in loops using dedicated macros.
snapscore.subtitle: Automate the web interface to raise a Snap Score from a single machine

snapchat.title: About Snapchat
snapchat.description: Snapchat is a social network centered on sending ephemeral photos and videos. Snap Score increases by repeating two simple actions:
snapchat.context: With manual use, most accounts stay in the hundreds or a few thousand points. Reaching the millions is rare.

origin.title: Project origin
origin.intro: I wanted to measure how far a Snap Score could go by automating the interface like a human would, on a single machine and without servers.

steps.title: Mobile prototype
steps.desc: Two phones with simple macros establish a baseline of ~30 points/min. Enough to validate the idea and show that multiplying devices doesn‚Äôt scale.

steps.title: Web userscript
steps.desc: A Tampermonkey script that clicks through the web UI proves feasibility and doubles throughput to ~60 points/min, but the computer must stay focused on visible windows.

steps.title: Node.js/Puppeteer orchestrator
steps.desc: Multi-window control (dual main session plus assistants) with locks, short pauses and restart rules: the desktop remains usable while climbing to ~460 points/min across nine windows.

origin.focus: The orchestrator changes everything: it coordinates visibility, prevents collisions and recovers automatically.

architecture.title: Technical architecture
architecture.objective: Maximize the main account‚Äôs score by coordinating helper accounts locally, keeping steady throughput without remote infrastructure.
components: Local orchestrator (Node.js + Puppeteer) that opens, drives and supervises each window.
Main account split across two parallel windows to maximize useful sends.
Assistant accounts dedicated to opening snaps and feeding the backlog.
A scheduler that assigns roles, paces sends/reads and monitors session health.
resourceManagement: Camera lock: only one send at a time on the main account.
Controlled backlog: automatic pause beyond 25 unread snaps to drain the queue.
Threshold restarts: a window is restarted when send/read latency exceeds ~1 s, which brings reads back to ~500 ms and sends to ~700 ms after reset.
Visibility guardrails: every action waits for the targeted element to exist and be visible, faster on average and without arbitrary timers.
observability: Per-window counters: successful sends/reads, queue size, and p50/p95 latencies.
startCheckingIssues loop: aggregates averages, computes points/min and triggers targeted restarts (main, assistants or global).
Structured logs (startLog) with session duration, send/read averages, backlog and blocked/healthy states.
Automatic slowdowns or restarts as soon as p95 drifts.
stack: Initial prototype as a Tampermonkey userscript

mobile.label: Mobile prototype
mobile.objective: Validate the idea: sync one phone that sends and another that opens to measure the real gain.
advantages: Close to normal app usage, so very low risk.
limits: Multiple phones plugged in continuously.
Camera and apps unavailable during the session.
Finicky macro tuning.

web.label: Web userscript
web.objective: Speed up cleanly: automate through the browser to chain sends/reads while keeping live visibility.
advantages: Clear settings, fast tests, easy iterations.
Browser tools help understand and fix quickly.
limits: PC monopolized without a second screen.
Any Snapchat UI change breaks the automation.
Platform defenses: throttling, dropped sessions.
Camera and mic monopolized by the browser, possible conflicts.
On long sessions: slowdowns and growing memory.

puppeteer.label: Puppeteer orchestrator
puppeteer.objective: Maximize score: run multiple accounts in parallel on one machine with simple rules, priorities and continuous monitoring.
advantages: Each account isolated with automatic reconnection.
Windows visible or hidden, scheduled launches and regular checks.
Fine-grained resource control: who gets the camera, when to restart, how to avoid bottlenecks.
Centralized monitoring with clear indicators updated every second.
Can be deployed on other machines if needed.
limits: Performance depends on hardware: CPU, RAM, disk, video encoding.
Memory grows with the number of instances.
puppeteer.perf: ~430 points/min on my setup with 2 main accounts and 7 assistants

observation.title: Findings before the final version
items: A Snapchat account can be connected in two places at the same time.
Leaving a session open too long ends up slowing everyone down.
The camera can‚Äôt be used by two instances simultaneously.
observation.conclusion: These findings guided the rules: limit session duration, queue camera access and restart as soon as metrics drift.

management.title: Instance management
items: An AccountManager supervises the accounts: connection, health checks and role assignment.
Each account has its own browser profile with saved cookies to reconnect automatically.
Main accounts send snaps, assistants open them.

monitoring.title: Continuous monitoring
items: Each window directly watches its conversation to act at the right moment, without arbitrary timers.
Aggregated counters track sends, reads, averages and backlog size in real time.
These metrics refresh in the console every 500 ms to keep tight control of the system.

rules.title: Resource rules
items: Camera lock: only one account has camera access at a time.
Controlled queue: pause as soon as more than 25 snaps remain unread.
Targeted restarts when send or open averages drift.
Auto-reconnect: if a window closes or numbers go off the rails, cut and relaunch cleanly.

remark.title: Note
remark.description: Experimental personal project. Automating the interface may go against the terms of service. The code is limited to local automation of a public interface.

learnings.title: What this demonstrates
items: Stability (locks, thresholds, restarts) matters more than raw speed.
A well-tuned local orchestrator is enough to manage multiple accounts without remote infrastructure.
Simple rules like the camera lock, backlog limit and latency guard make the system predictable and easy to fix.

ariesmod.title: Aries Mod
ariesmod.description: Community Tampermonkey mod for Magic Garden that brought together over 10,000 players, with a dedicated backend and integrated community hub
ariesmod.subtitle: A Tampermonkey userscript for the game Magic Garden that brought together over 10,000 players

game.title: About Magic Garden
game.description: Magic Garden is a multiplayer idle game available on Discord and magicgarden.gg. The concept: buy seeds, grow plants, sell them and get richer over time. Mechanics like pets (offering bonuses), weather (influencing prices) and multiplayer (up to 6 players, with sell bonuses based on room size) add depth to what seems like a childish game at first glance.

origin.title: Project Origin
origin.intro: It all started during a Discord evening with friends. We stumbled upon this game by accident, and honestly, my first reaction was: "It's childish, the gameplay really isn't great." But very quickly, an idea crossed my mind.

steps.title: The discovery
steps.desc: "OK the game sucks, but can't I just try to become the richest player?" My developer instinct kicked in instantly.

steps.title: Reverse engineering
steps.desc: I started dissecting the game: reading the minified JavaScript bundle, analyzing network requests, breaking down every WebSocket message. The goal, understand every mechanism to figure out what I could exploit.

steps.title: The first mod
steps.desc: I built a first mod focused on automation to accumulate money quickly and posted it on the game's public Discord. No rules, no security, the game had only been out for two months.

steps.title: Meeting the devs
steps.desc: A game developer reached out to me. Supportive, he said he was happy someone was taking interest in his game this early, but that this type of mod wasn't allowed. And that's when I saw another opportunity.

steps.title: The real beginning
steps.desc: What if, instead of automating, I created a community mod that players actually need? A mod that enhances the experience without breaking the game. That's where the real project started, systematically asking for dev approval before every feature.

origin.conclusion: This transparent approach built a trust relationship with the developers that allowed the project to grow for months.

client.label: Client (Userscript)
client.objective: Create a Tampermonkey mod that enriches the Magic Garden experience without breaking the game, adding community features and quality-of-life improvements that players are asking for.
client.story_intro: The mod evolved over months, each feature added in response to community needs and validated by the game developers.

story_steps.title: The foundations
story_steps.desc: First official version with the most requested features from the community. The mod was immediately adopted by players.

story_steps.title: The takeoff
story_steps.desc: The game had no public room system, yet playing with more people increases sell prices. I created a Discord bot coupled with the game's API to list available rooms directly in the mod. This is when the mod really took off.

story_steps.title: Editor mode
story_steps.desc: An idea that surprised everyone, developers included. A purely visual mode, but one that dramatically boosted the community aspect of the game.

story_steps.title: Constant maintenance
story_steps.desc: The game was being updated constantly. Multiple mod updates per week, sometimes per day. Core systems were rebuilt several times: sprite system, game data system, Discord compatibility.

src/
  ariesModAPI/  # Community API integration

  ui/  # User interface (menus, overlays)
  utils/  # Utilities

features: Pet manager: team creation, drag-to-reorder, auto-feed by species, ability logs
Notifications: rare shop item alerts, weather events, pet food levels
Public rooms: community-fed room listing with sell bonuses
Editor mode: full creative mode, all plants and decor unlocked in every variation
Locker: crop protection based on plant mutations
In-game QoL: Buy All, Sell All, inventory sorting, value calculator, statistics
Full debug menu: real-time Jotai store viewer, game sprite and sound capture, live WebSocket messages, useful for other modders
Customizable keybinds and multi-browser compatibility (Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Opera GX, Discord)
And many more: the mod was developed daily for months, the full feature list is available on GitHub
limits: Highly sensitive to game updates (frequently changing minified bundle)
Discord Activities compatibility complex to maintain (multiple restrictions)
Frequent maintenance required (multiple updates per week or even per day)
Core systems rebuilt several times (sprites, game data)

backend.label: Backend (VPS)
backend.objective: Provide a lightweight and cost-effective infrastructure capable of supporting over 10,000 users to power the mod's community features: rooms, real-time chat, friends, groups and leaderboard.
backend.story_intro: The backend was born out of necessity. When the game's public room API was removed due to abuse, I decided to recreate this feature myself. Mod players would become the data providers themselves.

story_steps.title: Supabase phase
story_steps.desc: I had planned for 50 users maximum, the free tier of 500K requests/month should have been enough. Within 1 hour of deployment: already 50 users. Within 24 hours: 400. In less than a week: the quota was reached.

story_steps.title: VPS migration
story_steps.desc: Migrated to a Hetzner VPS in 2 days at ‚Ç¨3.6/month. Theoretical capacity: 20 million requests/day. A completely disproportionate optimization compared to Supabase.

story_steps.title: The Community Hub
story_steps.desc: With over 1,000 users, I decided to build what the game was truly missing: a real community system. Real-time chat, friend system, groups, leaderboard, customizable profiles with 7 privacy controls.

story_steps.title: Security and compatibility
story_steps.desc: Added Discord OAuth to secure authentication. SSE events didn't work on Discord, so I implemented long polling with an event system. Coded non-stop for a week to make everything compatible.

story_steps.title: The optimization
story_steps.desc: With 10,000 registered players and 500 connected simultaneously, the VPS was at 200% capacity with 5 million requests/day. Massive refactoring: smart requests, deduplication, optimized polling. Result: 900K requests/day, VPS stable at 25%. All on a ‚Ç¨3.6/month server.

story_steps.title: Ko-fi and supporters
story_steps.desc: I added a Ko-fi page without expecting much. Within one week, I had raised enough to cover over a year and a half of hosting. I decided to integrate Supporter badges into the Community Hub to thank contributors.

features: Public room system fed directly by mod players
Full Community Hub: real-time chat, friends, groups, leaderboard, real-time view of friends' garden, inventory and pets without being in their room
Secure authentication via Discord OAuth
Long polling with event system (workaround for Discord restrictions)
Admin dashboard for real-time backend monitoring
Massive optimization: from 5M to 900K requests/day, VPS at 25% capacity
limits: Polling-only architecture (no SSE due to Discord restrictions)
Single VPS without redundancy
Dependency on Discord OAuth for authentication

optimization_rules: In-memory TTL cache (30s) for global data (rooms, leaderboard, online players)
PostgreSQL-backed rate limiting per IP and per player, with IP blocklist
Long polling with waiter pattern: server holds request until an event arrives or timeout
Unified fan-out: a single push serves both SSE and long-polling consumers
Parallel aggregation: 11 queries via Promise.all for initial data load
Lazy presence sweep: timer only runs when players are connected
Recipient deduplication for presence events (friends + group members)
Bulk upserts for room players (single INSERT instead of N)
Partial and composite PostgreSQL indexes targeting frequent queries
Lazy room cleanup (cleanup-on-read, no cron needed)

gemini.label: Gemini (Next-gen)
gemini.objective: Start from scratch in collaboration with another developer to create the ultimate mod: future-proof, auto-adaptive to game updates, all-browser and mobile compatible, and designed to be easily forkable.
gemini.story_intro: After months of development on Aries Mod, the limitations of the original architecture became obvious. We decided with another developer to start over from scratch.

story_steps.title: The collaboration
story_steps.desc: Another developer was also playing the game and had his own mod. We decided to merge our two projects into one, starting from scratch with an architecture built to last.

story_steps.title: The architecture
story_steps.desc: Documented strict rules, a modular architecture with clear layers (atoms, globals, modules, features, UI), and a clean separation of concerns. No more hardcoded game data, everything is dynamically extracted.

story_steps.title: Compatibility
story_steps.desc: All-browser compatible from day one, mobile optimized, and designed so any developer can fork and add their own sections easily.

story_steps.title: Claude as copilot
story_steps.desc: The project architecture is largely managed with Claude. Workflows, rules, and skills are defined in the .claude directory, enabling much smarter and cleaner coding. Every contribution automatically follows these guidelines.

gemini.structure:
src/
  api/  # Public API (window.Gemini)
  atoms/  # Bridge to the game's Jotai store
  globals/  # Reactive derived variables
  modules/  # Game modules (Data, Sprite, Pixi, Audio...)
  features/  # 20+ independent features
  websocket/  # Capture and transport
  ui/  # Interface (Shadow DOM, components, sections)
  utils/  # Cross-cutting utilities
  main.ts  # Entry point
features: Modular architecture with documented strict rules
Auto-adaptation to game structure (no more hardcoded data)
All-browser compatible + mobile optimized
20+ independently toggleable features
Public API exposed (window.Gemini) for third-party scripts
Dynamic sprite system via MGSprite and data via MGData
limits: Still under active development
More complex architecture (steeper learning curve for contributors)

items.text: ‚Ç¨50 raised on Ko-fi in one week, enough to cover 1.5 years of hosting
A ‚Ç¨3.6/month VPS handling the entire ecosystem
Compatible with Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Opera GX and Discord Activities

learnings.title: What this project demonstrates
items: Reverse engineering is a powerful tool when used constructively and transparently
Underestimating your user base is the best mistake you can make, it forces you to learn scaling under real conditions
A well-configured ‚Ç¨3.6/month VPS can outperform ‚Ç¨25/month cloud solutions
Community trust is built through transparency and asking for permission rather than forgiveness
User feedback is the best fuel for a developer

remark.title: What's next
remark.description: This project represented months of intensive development, brought together a community of over 10,000 players, and generated enough support to cover more than a year and a half of hosting. It's now evolving into Gemini, a collaborative ground-up rewrite. The goal: a future-proof, auto-adaptive, all-browser, mobile-optimized mod designed to be easily forkable by other developers. The end of one chapter, the beginning of another.
